publications.name: Hype
publications.historicalNotes: Hype was a music magazine published out of River Edge, NJ, connected to the Word Up! publishing ecosystem. It was part of the Faces Magazines / Enoble Media family of teen entertainment publications based in the Paramus/River Edge area of Bergen County, NJ. The magazine focused on hip-hop and R&B music content for teen audiences. Note: A separate, unrelated modern publication called 'The Hype Magazine' exists today as an urban culture outlet but has no direct connection to the 1990s River Edge publication. No digitized archive of the original Hype magazine was found online.

publications.name: Black In Jersey
publications.missionStatement: Our Voices, Our Perspectives
publications.historicalNotes: Black In Jersey is a digital storytelling and media production company founded in 2021 and based in Trenton, New Jersey. Founded by a local news veteran, the publication centers the African diaspora experience, spotlighting culture and the unique tapestry of Black experiences across the state. They coach citizen journalists to amplify voices that shape New Jersey, building connections through news content and documentary-style storytelling.

publications.name: The Connection / North Jersey Connection
publications.missionStatement: "Largest African-American weekly newspaper in New Jersey.”
publications.historicalNotes: The North Jersey Connection was a biweekly African American newspaper published in Teaneck, NJ by Connection Publications. The Library of Congress catalogs it with LCCN sn92060412, with the earliest described issue being No. 9 (Oct. 22, 1983). The exact founding date is uncertain but falls in the early 1980s, consistent with the 1982 date. The paper was later succeeded by or renamed to The Connection (Teaneck, N.J.), LCCN sn88071369, which continued publication and grew to describe itself as 'News from a Black perspective' and the 'Largest African-American weekly newspaper in New Jersey.' The Connection was published by Ralph F. Johnson. The newspaper served Bergen County and northern New Jersey's Black community, providing local news coverage from a Black perspective during a period when Teaneck was one of the first communities in the nation to voluntarily desegregate its schools (1965). The Library of Congress holds the catalog record, though physical copies may be held at other libraries.

publications.name: Front Runner New Jersey
publications.primaryFocus: African-American & Latino culture and leadership in South Jersey.
publications.missionStatement: Front Runner New Jersey brings a new perspective on the people, events and issues making an impact on African-Americans in South Jersey and the nation.
publications.historicalNotes: Front Runner New Jersey is a property of AC JosepH Media, LLC, founded by award-winning journalist Clyde Hughes who serves as president, CEO, and editor-in-chief. Based in Atlantic City, the publication covers African American and Latino communities in South Jersey, spanning Atlantic, Burlington, Camden, Cape May, Cumberland, Gloucester, and Salem counties. The outlet also launched a sister publication, Front Runner La Prensa, to cover the Latino community.

publications.name: The Citizen
publications.missionStatement: "A weekly newspaper devoted to the moral, intellectual, and industrial improvement of the Negro race.”

publications.name: South Jersey Journal
publications.targetAudience: African American community in southern New Jersey
publications.historicalNotes: The South Jersey Journal published its first edition in September 2011 and was a monthly publication covering news and information relevant to the African American community in South Jersey. Owned by South Jersey Communications, LLC, with President & Publisher Al Thomas and Editor-in-Chief Clyde Hughes, the journal was distributed at retail locations including ShopRite, Kmart, Superfresh, and Wawa. The publication eventually folded, becoming part of the broader decline of Black print media outlets nationally.

publications.name: The Newark Herald
publications.missionStatement: Dramatized the grievances and aspirations of African Americans in New Jersey, serving as a powerful voice for civil rights activities and political organizing in the Black community.
publications.historicalNotes: Published by the Newark Herald Publishing Co. as a weekly African American newspaper. Bibliographic description based on Vol. 11, no. 18 (June 11, 1938). The Herald's founder formed or helped form numerous political organizations including the Negro Progressive Republican League and the Young Men's Colored Republican Association of the City of Newark. Banner headlines addressed issues like 'Poor Housing Conditions are Assailed in Englewood' and 'Negro Must Use Politics to Win Rights.' Succeeded by the New Jersey Herald News (1938-1966). Historian Clement Price noted: 'Had not the black press in New Jersey dramatized the grievances and aspirations of the race, civil rights activities would have been without a powerful voice.' Available on microfilm at Newark Public Library and Rutgers Alexander Library. Newark Public Library has digitized issues in their African American Newark Newspapers collection.

publications.name: The Sentinel
publications.missionStatement: "Trenton’s first – and one of the state’s earliest – Black newspapers.”
publications.keyStaff: Founded, edited and published by R. Henri Herbert.
publications.historicalNotes: Founded by R. Henri Herbert, The Sentinel was Trenton's first and New Jersey's earliest African American newspaper. Herbert, born in 1857, began publishing the staunchly Republican weekly in his early twenties. Publication ran from Vol. I, no. 8 (June 26, 1880) through Vol. III, no. 19 (November 13, 1882). Herbert asserted the paper stood for 'earnest advocacy of the broadest freedom and purest liberty for white men, black men, Chinamen, and all men alike.' Advertisers included the Irish National Land & Industrial League, the Ancient Order of Hibernians, the local National Guard regiment, and the local Grand Army of the Republic chapter. The Sentinel later merged with the Trenton Herald at 4 North Broad Street. Herbert was a native of Trenton, son of Mansfield Herbert, a cabinet maker and artistic picture framer (whose clients included John A. Roebling). Henri's sister Priscilla Herbert was the first African American to graduate from the State Normal School (now College of New Jersey) in 1879. Issues were digitized from microfilm created by the Committee on Negro Studies of the American Council of Learned Societies and are available through Chronicling America.

publications.name: The Northern New Jersey Informer
publications.historicalNotes: No specific archival or historical records were found for The Northern New Jersey Informer in online databases including the Library of Congress, New Jersey State Library digitized newspapers, Chronicling America, or the Wikipedia list of African American newspapers in New Jersey. The publication does not appear in the New Jersey Historical Society newspaper inventory. It may have been a short-lived local community newspaper serving Paterson's African American population, which numbered approximately 8,270 (about 6% of the city's 139,336 residents) in the 1950 census. Physical copies or microfilm may exist at the Paterson Free Public Library, the Passaic County Historical Society, or in the Danky & Hady bibliography 'African-American Newspapers and Periodicals: A National Bibliography' (Harvard University Press, 1998).

publications.name: Five Wards Media
publications.targetAudience: Residents of Newark, New Jersey, especially youth and those impacted by systemic injustices
publications.missionStatement: To honor and amplify our community's vibrant stories, culture, and information needs.
publications.historicalNotes: Five Wards Media grew out of the Newark News & Story Collaborative, co-founded by Brit Harley, a Newark native and former WBGO 88.3fm community engagement reporter. The initiative launched during a 2021 JSK Community Impact Fellowship, with backing from the Geraldine R. Dodge Foundation and the Victoria Foundation. The outlet was part of the first cohort of Tiny News Collective members in 2021 and has trained over 20 Newark residents as reporting fellows through its community media incubator.

publications.name: City News
publications.historicalNotes: City News was a Black publication from Plainfield, NJ, circa 1983. Limited information is available online. Plainfield had an active Black press during this period; the Library of Congress catalogs 'Plainfield Today' (1983-1988), published by Henry Johnson, as another Black newspaper from the same city and era. The Plainfield Public Library's Local History Department holds the largest newspaper archive in Union County and may have copies. City News appears on the Wikipedia list of African American newspapers in New Jersey.

publications.name: New Jersey Record
publications.historicalNotes: No verifiable record found for an African American newspaper specifically titled 'New Jersey Record' published in Newark. Extensive searches of the Library of Congress newspaper directory, Chronicling America, Newark Public Library digital collections, Rutgers University Libraries, and the Wikipedia list of African-American newspapers in New Jersey returned no matches for this title. It is possible this title has been conflated with the 'New Jersey Afro American' (1941-1991, Newark edition of the Afro-American chain) or another Newark publication. The name may also refer to a short-lived or hyper-local publication not indexed in major catalogs. Recommended: contact the Newark Public Library's Charles F. Cummings NJ Information Center at njreference@npl.org or (973) 733-7775, or the James Brown African American Room, for verification.

publications.name: African World
publications.missionStatement: “The People’s Link”

publications.name: New Jersey Herald News
publications.publishers: New Jersey Herald News Pub. Co
publications.missionStatement: Described as 'Owned and published by New Jersey Negroes,' serving the African American community of Newark and Essex County.
publications.keyStaff: Previous editor (s): Oliver W. Brown. Supersedes: Absorbed: Newark Herald. Merged with: Advance to form: Herald-Advance.
publications.historicalNotes: Published by the New Jersey Herald News Publishing Co. beginning May 1938, ceasing around 1966. Weekly English-language newspaper edited by Oliver W. Brown (O.W. Brown). Succeeded The Newark Herald (1928-1939). Earliest description based on Vol. 1, No. 3 (May 21, 1938). Later succeeded by the Advance (Newark, 1965-1966) and Herald-Advance (Newark, 1966-). Digitized issues from 1938 available via Internet Archive. Also available through Newark Public Library Digital Archive.

publications.name: Trenton Journal
publications.targetAudience: Residents of Trenton, New Jersey, particularly underserved communities
publications.primaryFocus: Aims to address the information gaps and amplify voices in New Jersey’s capital city through solutions-based journalism.
publications.missionStatement: To provide the people of Trenton with accurate, independent, and meaningful journalism that informs, empowers, and uplifts our community.
publications.historicalNotes: The Trenton Journal is an independently owned and operated multimedia platform founded around 2020 by Kenneth M., who serves as Founder and Publisher. It was welcomed into the URL Media network, which recognized its commitment to bridging information gaps and providing community news for Trenton's nearly 90,000 residents. The publication focuses on solutions-based journalism to address information inequities in New Jersey's capital city.

publications.name: The Liberator
publications.historicalNotes: No specific records were found for a publication called The Liberator published in Paterson, NJ around 1950 in the African American press context. This title should not be confused with William Lloyd Garrison's famous abolitionist newspaper The Liberator (Boston, 1831-1865), nor with the 1960s New York-based Liberator magazine (1961-1971) associated with the Black liberation movement. The Paterson Liberator may have been a small community newspaper serving the city's growing African American population during the postwar era. Physical records may exist at the Newark Public Library's New Jersey Information Center, the Passaic County Historical Society, or in the Danky & Hady national bibliography of African American newspapers and periodicals.

publications.name: NJ in Color
publications.publishers: Tevra L. Francis, Publisher; tevMedia, LLC
publications.targetAudience: African American, Black, Latino, Asian, and BIPOC communities in Northern New Jersey
publications.missionStatement: NJ In Color is a platform designed to introduce you to all of the people, places, and personalities that make North Jersey so special.
publications.historicalNotes: NJ in Color is a digital publication based in Leonia, New Jersey, focused on connecting to the diversity of North Jersey. The outlet covers lifestyle, events, philanthropy, and news across Northern NJ communities including Bergen County, Englewood, Teaneck, Hackensack, Newark, Montclair, Paterson, Jersey City, and surrounding areas. The publication also maintains a New Jersey Black & POC Business Directory.

publications.name: New Jersey Urban News
publications.primaryFocus: Local news, stories often overlooked by mainstream media
publications.missionStatement: “A Voice for the Voiceless.”
publications.keyStaff:
CEO, Publisher, Co-Founder: Penda Howell
Co-founder, COO: Dorothy Howell
publications.historicalNotes: NJ Urban News is a BIPOC-led digital newsroom co-founded by CEO Penda Howell, headquartered at 625 Broad Street in Newark, New Jersey. The publication is committed to covering stories often overlooked by mainstream media that impact the 1.1 million people making up New Jersey's Black community. It is recognized as a Black-owned media outlet by the African American Chamber of Commerce of New Jersey.

publications.name: Nite Lite
publications.missionStatement: “Be in the know, on where to go.”

publications.name: Ark Republic
publications.targetAudience: Readers interested in the Black experience across the globe
publications.missionStatement: Telling stories, changing the conversation.
publications.historicalNotes: Ark Republic is a member-funded media outlet founded in 2017 and based at 142 Lafayette St, Newark, NJ. Described as a revolutionary, member-fueled media company, it is a collective of journalists, scholars, artists, and activists committed to telling rich and robust narratives about the Black experience globally. Notable recognitions include being named a Company to Watch by NYU Entrepreneurial Institute (2018), Comcast RISE recipient (2020), Newark Creative Catalyst (2021), and joining CUNY's Black Media Project inaugural cohort (2022).

publications.name: The Newark Times
publications.targetAudience: Residents and stakeholders of Newark, New Jersey
publications.primaryFocus: News, arts, business, science & technology, lifestyle, food & drink, Finance
publications.missionStatement: The Newark Times is dedicated to sharing the perspectives and narratives of Newark’s history, emergence, challenges, and triumphs with dignity, honesty, and candor.
publications.keyStaff:
Tehsuan Glover - Publisher
Viviana Salgado - Creative Director
publications.historicalNotes: The Newark Times is a digital publication dedicated to sharing the perspectives and narratives of Newark's history, emergence, and triumphs with dignity, honesty, and candor. The outlet covers Newark community news including economic development, arts events, and nonprofit investments in the city. It operates via thenewarktimes.com as part of the broader ecosystem of Newark-focused community media.

publications.name: The Newark Herald
publications.publishers: New Jersey Herald News Pub. Co. (related to Herald-Advance lineage)

publications.name: Atlantic City Focus
publications.targetAudience: African American community in Atlantic City and surrounding BIPOC communities
publications.primaryFocus: News, politics, art, entertainment, black history, culture
publications.missionStatement: “If It's Important to you, It's important to us!”
publications.historicalNotes: Atlantic City Focus is a hyper-local news platform founded by Mark Tyler, who holds a BA in Journalism from Columbia Union College (now Washington Adventist University) and previously interned at The Press of Atlantic City. The publication covers Atlantic City's arts, culture, and entertainment through an African American lens. It has participated in collaborative journalism efforts overseen by the Center for Cooperative Media at Montclair State University.

publications.name: Harambee
publications.missionStatement: “A newspaper for young readers that focuses on the African American experience.”

publications.name: Greater News
publications.publishers: Greater News of Northern New Jersey

publications.name: Black Newark
publications.primaryFocus: Politics, News, Protest literature, Protest works.
publications.missionStatement: “The Voice of New Ark’s Inner City.”
publications.keyStaff: Previous editor(s): Abu Ansar, Apr-Nov 1968; Yusef Iman, Jan 1970; Daoud Abdullah, Jan 1970; Simba Risasi, Apr-May 1972.
publications.historicalNotes: Black Newark was the first in a series of interconnected newspapers published under the leadership of Amiri Baraka (LeRoi Jones) through the Committee for Unified Newark (CFUN) and its successor organizations. The publication sequence was: Black Newark (Vol. 1, Nos. 1-3, April-November 1968), then Black News (Vol. 1, No. 4, 1969, published by Black People of Newark), then Black New Ark (Vol. 1, No. 5, April 1972 through Vol. 2, No. 14, December 1973, published by CFUN), and finally Unity and Struggle (Vol. 3, No. 1, January/February 1974 through Vol. 8, No. 1/2, February 1979, published by CFUN as the national newspaper of the Congress of Afrikan People). These newspapers were published through the post-rebellion period of Newark, serving as tools for organizing and advocating for Black liberation and political and economic agency for Newark's majority Black citizenry. Baraka served as chairman of CFUN from 1968 to 1975. The movement documented in these papers contributed to the Black and Puerto Rican alliance that led to the election of Newark's first Black mayor, Kenneth Gibson, in 1970. The newspapers also covered Baraka's community-based initiatives addressing housing conditions, failing schools, and economic opportunities, including the Kawaida Towers apartment project and NJR-32 urban renewal project. The collection is digitized and searchable through the Rutgers Dana Library Newark Black Newspapers Collection. Additional copies are held at the NYU Tamiment Library and the Auburn Avenue Research Library. Scholarly treatment includes Jennifer Caroccio Maldonado's article 'Putting the Black Ink Back into Print: Black Newark/Black New Ark' in New Jersey Studies: An Interdisciplinary Journal 8(1), Winter 2022, pp. 34-49.

publications.name: Faithfully Magazine
publications.missionStatement: Faithfully Magazine amplifies conversations, issues, and events affecting diverse communities.
publications.historicalNotes: Faithfully Magazine was founded in 2016 by religion writer Nicola A. Menzie and is published by Faithfully Media, LLC, based at 397 Hillside Avenue, Hillside, NJ. The publication is a fresh, bold news and culture outlet centering on Christian communities of color, and has been featured in The Washington Post, Christianity Today, Fortune Magazine, WNYC, and other major outlets. It publishes exclusive Q&As, features, and commentaries reflecting influential voices in U.S. Christianity.

publications.name: North Jersey Independent
publications.historicalNotes: No specific archival records were found for the North Jersey Independent from Paterson in online databases. A related publication, the New Jersey Herald News (Newark, 1938-1966), was described as 'Independent' and 'Owned and published by New Jersey Negroes' with editor O.W. Brown, but this was a separate Newark-based publication. The North Jersey Independent may have been a community newspaper serving Paterson's African American residents. Physical copies may survive at the Paterson Free Public Library, the New Jersey State Archives, or in the comprehensive Danky & Hady bibliography.

publications.name: The Echo
publications.primaryFocus:
• African Americans--New Jersey--Newspapers.
• African Americans.--fast--(OCoLC)fst00799558
• New Jersey.--fast--(OCoLC)fst01208379
publications.missionStatement: Published weekly 'in interest of Negro race.' Empowered communities of color with a platform to express opinions and interests on local, national, and international current affairs.
publications.keyStaff:
Rock, William E.
Howard, Reuben J.
publications.historicalNotes: Founded in 1904 by William Elijah Rock in Long Branch, NJ. Rock was born at Pine Brook, NJ on January 22, 1861, son of Peter and Emma (Schanck) Rock, whose grandfather came from Africa and settled in New Jersey around 1700. Rock was educated in public schools at Pine Brook, received private instruction under Prof. John R. Porter in New York for 4 years, and read law in the office of T.W. Throckmorton in Red Bank for 8 years. The newspaper was named after his Lenni-Lenape mother Emma Schanck-Rock, per her original tribal name translated to English. Publishers listed as Rock and Howard. Relocated from Long Branch to Red Bank in 1909, established with capital of $50. Rock died in June 1933 and the paper folded in 1943. Was described as 'The oldest colored paper in New Jersey.' Per The State Historical Society of Wisconsin's Who's Who of the Colored Race Volume One (1915), Rock is listed alongside Madame C.J. Walker. Original issues available at Red Bank Public Library digital collection.

publications.name: Trenton365 Stream with Jacque Howard
publications.targetAudience: Diverse residents of the greater Trenton area, including immigrant families from Central and South America, Southeast and Central Asia, Eastern Europe, and Africa
publications.missionStatement: A micro-media organization that encourages people and organizations to be more civically engaged.
publications.historicalNotes: Trenton365 was founded by Jacque Howard as a community-building program and media outlet encouraging private citizens, nonprofit groups, and businesses in the greater Trenton area to become more civically minded. Howard, who previously served as executive director of Urban Mission Cabinet Inc., started the radio program about getting things moving in a positive direction in Trenton. The name references the year-round commitment required to address challenges in New Jersey's capital city, and its content is translated into several languages including Spanish, Filipino, and Igbo to serve Trenton's diverse population.

publications.name: The Black Observer
publications.missionStatement: “Power is the Only Argument that Satisfies Man.”
publications.historicalNotes: The Black Observer was a community-oriented newspaper produced by Rutgers-Camden students affiliated with the Black Student Unity Movement (BSUM). A complete surviving issue dates to circa fall 1969. The paper was created by student activists for the broader Camden community during the height of the Black Power movement. The editorial team included Roy Jones, Marie Spearman, Faye Waters, Myrna Williams, Vince Mayfield, Carolyn Williams, Ralph Spencer, Richard Rhodes, Alice Syms, Linda Ellis, R. Eugene Kirkland, Lillian Matthews, Fredia Bodie, and Betty Coleman. A letter from Aaron G. Thompson on behalf of the Rutgers BSUM appears on page 5 of the surviving issue. The complete issue is housed in Special Collections at the Paul Robeson Library, Rutgers University-Camden, as part of the Campus Ephemera Collection within the broader 'Black Student Activism in Camden' collection.

publications.name: The Landscape
publications.historicalNotes: A four-page monthly newspaper written, printed, and published by A.P. Smith from his home at 171 East Allendale Road (corner of Chestnut Ridge Road) in Saddle River, Bergen County, NJ. First published in 1881 (not 1885 as sometimes cited), it continued until Smith's death in 1901. Originally intended as 'A LETTER TO OUR FRIENDS on matters of interest,' it contained neighborhood news, political commentary, and local advertisements. Smith served as editor, printer, and publisher. The newspaper is considered a valuable resource for Saddle River Valley historical research. The history of A.P. Smith and The Landscape has been the subject of lectures by Arnold E. Brown, civil rights leader and founder of the Du Bois Book Center in Englewood, who was also the first African American from Bergen County elected to the NJ State Legislature.

publications.name: New Jersey Afro-American
publications.missionStatement:
“Champion of Civic Welfare and the Square Deal.” 
"[T]he longest running and most widely read black newspaper in New Jersey.”
publications.keyStaff: Previous editor(s): Cliff MacKay, July 1 1954-Feb 3 1968; Moses J. Newson, Feb 10 1968-July 8 1978; Raymond H. Boone, July 15 1978-Apr 11 1981; Robert C. Queen, Apr 18 1981-Oct 11 1986; Robert W. Matthews, Oct 19 1986- [Feb 6 1988].
publications.historicalNotes: The New Jersey Afro-American was the Newark regional edition of the Baltimore-based Afro-American newspaper chain, one of the most influential African American newspaper enterprises in the United States. Published weekly by the Afro-American Company from Vol. 1, No. 1 (March 15, 1941) through 1991, it served the African American communities of Newark and East Orange in Essex County, New Jersey. The parent Afro-American newspaper was founded in 1892 by John H. Murphy Sr. in Baltimore and expanded under editor Carl J. Murphy (who led the paper for 45 years starting in 1922) to include nine national editions in 13 major cities. At its peak, regional weekly editions were published in Baltimore, Washington D.C., Philadelphia, Richmond, and Newark. The chain employed notable journalists and intellectuals including Langston Hughes, William Worthy, and J. Saunders Redding. It was the first Black newspaper to employ a female sportswriter (Lillian Johnson and Nell Dodson in the mid-1930s), and artist Romare Bearden began his career as a cartoonist there in 1936. During World War II, the Afro-American stationed reporters in Europe, the Aleutians, Africa, Japan, and other parts of the South Pacific; Elizabeth Murphy Phillips Moss was the first Black female war correspondent. The New Jersey edition adopted Afro-American numeration in 1979. Princeton University Library holds microfilm copies from March 15, 1941 through 1972. The parent Afro-American remains in publication today as the oldest family-owned African American newspaper in the United States. LCCN: sn84025926.

publications.name: More Jersey
publications.targetAudience: New Jersey residents statewide, particularly Black communities
publications.primaryFocus: Local businesses and organizations, community events
publications.missionStatement: More Jersey is a community media startup with a statewide footprint, dedicated to connecting individuals with local businesses and organizations, informing communities of activities to enhance their lives, and inspiring NJ residents to take action.
publications.historicalNotes: More Jersey is a community media startup founded by Joe Campbell, committed to producing content, merchandise, and events to inform, connect, and inspire New Jersey residents. The outlet serves as a statewide one-stop resource covering government, community, arts and culture, finance, and events spanning the entire state. Campbell has noted the company's focus on the up-trend in audio and video-based content, including developing short-form video series to celebrate the New Jersey experience.

publications.name: The New Jersey Guardian
publications.missionStatement: “Voice of the Colored People.”
publications.historicalNotes: Published weekly in Newark, Essex County, NJ by the N.J. Guardian Pub. Co. Began with the September 29, 1934 issue; ceased in 1942 (exact end date uncertain). Carried the motto 'Voice of the Colored People.' Bibliographic description based on Vol. 6, no. 27 (Oct. 28, 1939). Cataloged by the Library of Congress under African Americans -- New Jersey -- Newspapers. The Library of Congress may not hold copies; holdings may exist at other libraries.

publications.name: New Jersey Trumpet
publications.missionStatement: Served the Black community in Jersey City and Newark during the late 19th century as a voice for African American interests in New Jersey.
publications.historicalNotes: A weekly newspaper published by Col. William H. Murrell (listed as 'Wm. Murrell'). First issue December 29, 1887; ceased around 1897. Originally based in Jersey City, it relocated to Newark in 1889. Murrell was born into slavery in Georgia and served during the Civil War as a valet to Confederate General Longstreet, later enlisting in the 44th regiment Virginia and South Carolina troops. After the war he moved to Louisiana, served in the State Legislature for nine years, and was a colonel of the 4th Regiment, Louisiana State National Guard. After losing his possessions in the great flood of 1878 and receiving death threats from the KKK, he moved to Washington D.C. (Treasury Department), then to New Jersey in 1883 where he established The Trumpet. His wife Louisiana served as business manager. Two of their sons, William Frederick and Wellington, were killed in the Spanish-American War and are buried in Arlington National Cemetery.

publications.name: The Forum
publications.missionStatement: "Serving the New Jersey black community."

publications.name: The Nubian News
publications.missionStatement: "New Jersey's only African-American-Hispanic news source.”
publications.keyStaff: Editor: Kamau Kujichagulia, Previous editor(s): Pamela A. Sims
publications.historicalNotes: The Nubian News was founded circa 1988-1989 by publisher Kamau Kujichagulia and is the only bilingual (English and Spanish) African American newspaper in New Jersey. Based at 25 South Westfield Avenue, Trenton, NJ 08618, the newspaper has been in continuous publication for over 35 years, covering local events, politics, and community issues relevant to Trenton's Black community. Kujichagulia remains the publisher and key principal. The Nubian News also produces the podcast 'On The Case,' featuring weekly interviews with community leaders every Thursday at 8 PM EST. The paper gained wider attention in 2020 when Kujichagulia organized a rally in support of Trenton councilwoman Robin Vaughn. The Nubian News Corporation operates the newspaper's current digital presence at thenubiannews.com. No digitized historical archive of print issues was found online.

publications.name: The Voice
publications.historicalNotes: The Voice was an African American weekly newspaper published in Plainfield, New Jersey by Voice Associates. It began publication in 1968, notably just one year after the 1967 Plainfield riots (part of the broader Long Hot Summer of 1967), which were a watershed event for the city's African American community. The Library of Congress catalog description is based on Vol. 4, No. 5 (Jan. 24, 1971), confirming it was still publishing at least into its fourth year. The paper was illustrated and measured 44 cm. Its LCCN is sn88063027 and OCLC number is 17430825. The end date of publication is listed as unknown in Library of Congress records. The Library of Congress may not hold physical copies, but other libraries may have holdings.

publications.name: Essex Forum
publications.missionStatement: "A weekly newspaper serving Orange, Montclair and E. Orange," June 29, 1972-<July 26, 1973>; "A biweekly newspaper serving Metropolitan Essex County," <Feb. 14-Mar. 21, 1972>

publications.name: Public Square Amplified
publications.publishers: Josie Gonsalves - Founder and Executive Director
publications.missionStatement: PSA positions journalism as a civic tool and creates a pipeline for a new cadre of local journalists of color representing their geographic and ethnic communities.
publications.keyStaff:
Josie Gonsalves - Founder and Executive Director
Renee Johnston - Digital Administrator
publications.historicalNotes: Public Square Amplified (PSA) is a grassroots local nonprofit newsroom founded in 2021 by a team of Black women with over 40 years of combined experience in nonprofit, journalism, and community organizing sectors. Headquartered in Newark, PSA operates as a cooperative newsroom that positions journalism as a civic tool to amplify local voices. The organization receives provisional membership and fiscal sponsorship under the Institute for Nonprofit News and subscribes to its standards of editorial independence.

publications.name: Apex News
publications.primaryFocus: Fashion, Family, Marriage, Interior Decorating, General Interest, Poetry
publications.missionStatement: "The national magazine for Apex beauticians and agents.”

publications.name: The African Voice
publications.primaryFocus: Politics, Rutgers University (Camden, NJ), Africa, Book reviews, Community newsletter.

publications.name: Artz
publications.missionStatement: "The entertainment magazine."
publications.keyStaff: Editors: Lorraine Davis Hickman, Mar-Sept 1992; Jan M. Edgerton-Johnson, Oct 1992-Summer 1993

publications.name: Ash Can
publications.keyStaff: Previous editor(s): Bertram Totten. Superseded by: Penn Crusader
publications.historicalNotes: CCC camp newspaper. Associated with CCC Camp S-60 (Company 1284-C) at Penn State Forest, 13 miles south of Chatsworth, established October 30, 1933. No digitized copies found online. CCC camps in New Jersey were fully segregated by July 1935 per order of CCC Director Robert Fechner. Camp newspapers were a common feature of CCC camps, with an estimated 60-70 percent of camps producing their own publications. Further research recommended at the Center for Research Libraries (main repository for CCC camp newspapers) and National Archives Record Group 35.

publications.name: New Jersey Deadline
publications.publishers: Published by Deadline Publishing Company, Inc.
publications.historicalNotes: No verifiable record found for an African American newspaper titled 'New Jersey Deadline' published in Newark. Searches of the Library of Congress newspaper directory, Chronicling America, Newark Public Library inventories, Rutgers University Newark Archives Project, the New Jersey Historical Society newspaper listings, and the Wikipedia list of African-American newspapers in New Jersey returned no matches. The title does not appear in any known NJ newspaper catalog or microfilm inventory. This may be a very short-lived publication, an alternative name for another title, or possibly a misattribution. Recommended: contact the Newark Public Library NJ Information Center or the New Jersey Historical Society for further verification.

publications.name: CFUN News
publications.historicalNotes: CFUN News was the newsletter/newspaper of the Committee for Unified Newark (CFUN), the Black united front organization chaired by Amiri Baraka from 1968 to 1975. CFUN's primary publication was Black NewArk, first published in April 1968 as one of several media outlets Baraka developed to promote Black cultural nationalism. CFUN was formed after Ron Karenga and the US organization visited Baraka's Spirit House in Newark in 1967, driving a shift toward electoral organizing that led to the election of Newark's first Black mayor, Kenneth Gibson, in 1970. CFUN also operated a 'Black Newark' radio program on Newark Public Radio (c. 1970-72) where Baraka discussed topics from teachers' strikes to the origins of Kwanzaa. The publication sequence ran: Black Newark (Vol. 1, No. 1-3, April-November 1968), Black News (Vol. 1, No. 4, 1969), Black New Ark (Vol. 1, No. 5, April 1972 through Vol. 2, No. 14, December 1973), then Unity and Struggle (Vol. 3, No. 1, January/February 1974 onward). Digitized issues are in the Rutgers Dana Library Newark Black Newspapers Collection. Additional archival materials are in the Komozi Woodard Amiri Baraka Collection (Series IV, Box 3, Folder 6) at the Auburn Avenue Research Library, the Amiri Baraka Papers at Columbia University, and the George Washington University collection (1951-1988). The scholarly article 'Putting the Black Ink Back into Print: Black Newark/Black New Ark' by Jennifer Caroccio Maldonado (NJS: An Interdisciplinary Journal, Winter 2022) examines the publication's significance.

publications.name: Black Journal
publications.publishers: Jersey City State College, Affican/AfroAmerican Studies Center
publications.primaryFocus: African-American studies, Colleges and Universities — Students
publications.historicalNotes: No digitized archive or detailed historical record was found for the Black Journal of Jersey City, NJ (1979). The publication does not appear in the Library of Congress newspaper directory, the Wikipedia list of African American newspapers in New Jersey, the Newark Public Library microfilm inventory, or the New Jersey State Library's digitized newspaper index. It should not be confused with the nationally known PBS television program 'Black Journal' (1968-1977) hosted by Tony Brown, which later became 'Tony Brown's Journal.' The Jersey City Free Public Library's local history collections and the New Jersey Historical Society in Newark may hold physical records. The publication was likely a small-circulation community newspaper serving Jersey City's Black population during the late 1970s.

publications.name: Journal of African American Men
publications.publishers: Transaction Publishers; National Council of African American Men
publications.primaryFocus: Men, Research, Sociology, Psychology, Political Science
publications.historicalNotes: The Journal of African American Men was an academic quarterly published by Transaction Publishers in New Brunswick, NJ, from Vol. 1, No. 1 (Summer 1995) through Vol. 6, No. 4 (Spring 2002). It served as the official publication of the National Council of African American Men. The journal covered a range of scholarly topics relevant to African American men, including a notable special issue on 'Impacts of Incarceration on the African American Family' (Summer 2001). Transaction Publishers, based at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, was a leading academic publisher of social science journals and books. The Journal of African American Men was succeeded by the Journal of African American Studies, which continues publication. The complete archive is available through JSTOR.

publications.name: The Union Messenger
publications.historicalNotes: No digitized archive or detailed historical record was found for The Union Messenger of Camden, NJ (1979). The publication does not appear in the Library of Congress directory, the Wikipedia list of African American newspapers in New Jersey, or Camden County Library System catalogs. Camden had a significant African American community during this period, and the publication may have been a union-affiliated or community newsletter. The Camden County Historical Society holds vertical files, photograph collections, and African American historical materials that may contain records. The Black Camden Oral History Project (blackcamden.org) is actively documenting African American life and activism in Camden and may have knowledge of this publication.

publications.name: The Ironsides Echo
publications.historicalNotes: Student newspaper of the Manual Training and Industrial School for Colored Youth at Bordentown (the 'Bordentown School'), also known as 'the Tuskegee of the North.' The school was founded in 1886 (originally 1876) by Rev. Walter A. Rice, a former slave and AME Church minister, beginning with 10 students in two wood-clapboard homes on West Street. The name 'Ironsides' derives from the school's location on the former estate of Commodore Charles Stewart, commander of the USS Constitution ('Old Ironsides') during the War of 1812. Frances O. Grant founded the drama club and The Ironsides Echo, which won multiple prizes from organizations including the National Scholastic Association. Grant invited prominent figures including Mary McLeod Bethune, W.E.B. Du Bois, James Weldon Johnson, Paul Robeson, Albert Einstein, and Eleanor Roosevelt to speak at the school. The paper was printed by students in the printing trades program and served as outreach -- both white and Black schools exchanged papers with them. The front page of the May-June 1939 edition announced Mary McLeod Bethune as Commencement Speaker. William R. Valentine became principal in 1915, viewing the school as offering practical education, stating: 'We cannot all be doctors, lawyers, dentists, and preachers... Thus the need of men in the trades.' The school closed in 1955 following the Brown v. Board of Education decision. Digitized issues (from 1935 onward) available through the New Jersey State Library's DSpace repository.

publications.name: Yes: Youth Excited About Success
publications.missionStatement: “The magazine of the new generation.”

publications.name: En Avant
publications.historicalNotes: No digitized archive was found for En Avant, a Haitian diaspora publication from Newark, NJ (1972). 'En Avant' translates from French as 'Forward' or 'Onward.' Newark's Essex County has one of the largest Haitian communities in New Jersey, concentrated in the Vailsburg section and surrounding cities of Irvington, Orange, and East Orange. The early 1970s saw significant Haitian migration to the Northeast US fleeing the Duvalier dictatorships. Over 72 percent of New Jersey's Haitian population lives within the Archdiocese of Newark. The publication likely served as a community voice for Haitian immigrants during this wave of political exile. Known Haitian diaspora newspapers in the region include Haiti Liberte, which distributes in Newark, and The Haitian Times (founded 1999, Brooklyn). En Avant predates these and may be among the earliest Haitian community publications in New Jersey. The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture at NYPL and university archives specializing in Caribbean diaspora history may hold records.

publications.name: Black Women's United Front Newsletter
publications.primaryFocus: Women, Education, Prison reform, Economics, Book reviews
publications.historicalNotes: The Black Women's United Front (BWUF) was formally established on January 25, 1975, in Detroit, when over 500 activists from organizations including the Congress of African People (CAP), Youth Organization for Black Unity (YOBU), and the National Welfare Rights Organization came together. The BWUF was spearheaded by Amina Baraka (Sylvia Jones), wife of Amiri Baraka, who had led discussions about gender roles within CAP's Women's Division. Following the July 1974 All-Afrikan Women's Conference in Newark, NJ, Amina led over 800 men and women in forming the BWUF to develop 'an autonomous political and ideological agenda for African American women.' The organization committed to the 'abolition of every possibility of oppression & exploitation' and described itself as anti-racist, anti-capitalist, and anti-imperialist, rooted in working-class women. BWUF activities included political education forums, coalition building, support for the Joan Little case, and community forums on workplace rights, healthcare, and childcare. The BWUF published through Unity and Struggle rather than a standalone newsletter. Archival materials (1975-1976) are held in Series VII of the Komozi Woodard Amiri Baraka Collection at the Auburn Avenue Research Library on African American Culture and History, and are available on microfilm. Additional materials are accessible through the ProQuest History Vault (Penn Libraries) and the Bodleian Library at Oxford. Scholar Ashley Farmer's book 'Remaking Black Power: How Black Women Transformed an Era' draws extensively on these archives. The scholarly article 'Abolition of Every Possibility of Oppression: Black Women, Black Power, and the Black Women's United Front, 1970-1976' (Project MUSE) provides detailed analysis.

publications.name: The National Political Science Review
publications.publishers: National Conference of Black Political Scientists

publications.name: Afro-American Festival of the Arts Magazine
publications.historicalNotes: The Afro-American Festival of the Arts Magazine was published in August 1966 in Newark, New Jersey. It was edited and partially written by LeRoi Jones (later Amiri Baraka), whose name appears among the staff listed on page 8 of the publication. The magazine featured articles by Jones alongside Ed Spriggs, Sonia Sanchez, Larry Neal, Joe White, Yusef Inman, Ben Caldwell, and others -- many of whom were key figures in the emerging Black Arts Movement. The publication is connected to Baraka's Black Nationalist period, following his move from Greenwich Village to Newark in 1965 and the founding of the Spirit House theater. It was published in the same year that Baraka's Jihad Productions in Newark published his poetry collection 'Black Art,' the first volume of the three-part work 'Black Magic: Poems 1961-66.' A copy is held in the Harris Collection of American Poetry and Plays at Brown University Library.

publications.name: Today's Black Woman
publications.publishers: John Blassingame; New Day Associates, Inc.
publications.missionStatement: Print

publications.name: Spirit: The Guide to the Soul
Jersey Camera
publications.missionStatement: "Magazine for the home.”

publications.name: Bronze Thrills
publications.missionStatement: Bronze Thrills provided African American readers with romance, true confessions, and women's interest stories written in a style familiar to its audience. Its predecessor, The World's Messenger (founded 1942), was innovative in featuring stories written in the dialect of Southern working-class African Americans.
publications.keyStaff: Previous editor(s): Adelle Jackson; Edna K. Turner, Jan 1955; Eunice Wilson
publications.historicalNotes: Bronze Thrills was a Black romance and confessions-style magazine that evolved from The World's Messenger, founded in 1942 by Horace J. Blackwell, an African American minister and clothing merchant in Fort Worth, Texas. After Blackwell's death in 1949, his widow sold the publication to George T. Levitan, a white businessman, who renamed it Bronze Thrills and continued publishing through Good Publishing Company (also known as Sepia Publishing), based in Fort Worth. Good Publishing also produced the magazines Sepia, Hep, and Jive for African American audiences. Bronze Thrills featured true romance, true confessions, and women's interest articles alongside essays on African American issues. While Sepia did not equal the newsstand sales of Bronze Thrills, it was Sepia that became the most successful competitor to Ebony for nearly four decades. After Levitan's death in 1976, the publications were sold to Beatrice Pringle, returning them to Black ownership. The business closed around 1983. Note: All available sources identify Fort Worth, Texas as the base of Good Publishing. The connection to Dover, New Jersey may reflect a regional editorial or distribution office, but this could not be confirmed through online sources. The magazine's records and building were mostly destroyed after the business closed; the African American Museum in Dallas now holds the picture files.

publications.name: MEDIC News
publications.publishers: Minority Economic Development Industrial and Cultural Enterprise, Inc.
publications.historicalNotes: No digitized archive or detailed historical record was found for MEDIC News of Newark, NJ (1971). The publication does not appear in the Newark Public Library microfilm inventory, the Library of Congress directory, or standard African American newspaper bibliographies accessed online. Newark had an active Black health advocacy community during this period; the Concerned Black Nurses of Newark was formed to advocate healthcare for the underserved, and the Newark Public Library curated an exhibit titled 'Dear & Glorious Physician: The History of Black Doctors, Nurses and Hospitals in Newark and Places Just Beyond the River.' The 1970s saw Black communities organizing neighborhood health clinics and demonstration projects to address epidemics of hypertension, diabetes, and infant mortality. MEDIC News may have been connected to one of these community health initiatives. The Newark Public Library's New Jersey Information Center and the Rutgers Special Collections may hold physical copies.

publications.name: The Cricket: Black Music in Evolution
publications.primaryFocus: Music, Poetry, Short stories, Music reviews
publications.missionStatement: The Cricket aimed 'to provide Black Music with a powerful historical and critical tool' and to enable avant-garde Black musicians and writers 'to finally make a way for themselves.' It sought to reunite advanced art with its community and foster critical and political dialogue for Black musicians and writers.
publications.keyStaff: Previous editor(s): Le Roi Jones, Amamu Baraka, Larry Neal, A. B. Spellman
publications.historicalNotes: The Cricket: Black Music in Evolution was edited by Amiri Baraka, A.B. Spellman, and Larry Neal between 1968 and 1969. Published by Baraka's Newark-based Jihad Productions, it was a mimeographed experimental music magazine that ran for four issues. The Cricket emerged from the heart of the Black Arts Movement, published shortly after the 1967 Newark Rebellion. Over its four issues, it laid out an anticommercial ideology and took aim at the conservative jazz press, providing space for critics, poets, journalists, and musicians to devise new styles of music writing. It ran poetry, position papers, and gossip alongside concert and record reviews and essays on music and politics. Contributors included Albert Ayler, Milford Graves, Sun Ra, Cecil Taylor, Stanley Crouch, Haki Madhubuti (Don L. Lee), Ishmael Reed, Sonia Sanchez, Keorapetse Kgositsile, Mtume, Black Unity Trio, Ben Caldwell, Askia Muhammad Toure, and many others. The fourth issue (1969) is particularly notable for containing Albert Ayler's letter 'To Mr. Jones -- I had a Vision,' describing an intense UFO sighting/religious revelation Ayler and his brother experienced in New Jersey. The complete facsimile of all four issues was republished by Blank Forms Editions with an introduction by poet and scholar David Grundy, author of 'A Black Arts Poetry Machine: Amiri Baraka and the Umbra Poets' (Bloomsbury Academic, 2019).

publications.name: Deliverance Voice
publications.historicalNotes: No specific archival or historical records were found for the Deliverance Voice in online databases including the Library of Congress, Chronicling America, or the Wikipedia list of African American newspapers in New Jersey. The name suggests a possible connection to a religious organization or church community, as 'Deliverance' is a common term in African American church traditions. The publication appeared in 1967, the same year as the Newark Rebellion (July 12-17, 1967), which was a pivotal event that spurred significant community organizing and media production in Newark's African American community. Physical records may exist at the Newark Public Library's Charles F. Cummings New Jersey Information Center, the Rutgers University Libraries, or the New Jersey Historical Society.

publications.name: The Missionary Magazine
publications.publishers: Women's Missionary Society (WMS) of the AME Church
publications.primaryFocus: African Methodist Episcopal Church, Missions, Religion, Profiles

publications.name: Hours After
publications.missionStatement: “The picture guide to entertainment.”

publications.name: Utimme Umana/La Voz Oculta
publications.targetAudience: African American and Hispanic American students at Trenton State College
publications.keyStaff: Previous editor(s): Kingsley Ugorji, Nov/Dec 1985Apr/May 1986; Curt Broadway, Fall 1986-Dec/Jan 1986/87; Kris Tucker, Feb-Mar 1988; Faith Pennant, Sept/Oct 1989; Hore Caldwell, Nov/Dec 1989; Will A. Mitchell, Apr 1990; Raeshell Carter, Spring 1991; Michael C. Burton, Feb- Apr 1992; Anthony Maddot, Nov 1993.
publications.historicalNotes: Utimme Umana/La Voz Oculta was a minority student newspaper at Trenton State College (now The College of New Jersey). The original Utimme Umana was incorporated in 1968 as a Black student newspaper, though it initially struggled to gain footing. On October 2, 1972, the first issue of the combined Utimme Umana: La Voz Oculta was published, merging the Black student paper with a Hispanic voice. 'Utimme Umana' means 'rebirth' in Swahili, while 'La Voz Oculta' means 'the hidden voice' in Spanish. The paper's defining mission was to combat ignorance on the topics of race and it encouraged readers to help spread the word. The publication presented poetry, short stories, and essays relating predominantly to Black, Hispanic, and Latinx themes, along with social and cultural events, announcements, reviews, letters to the editor, photographs, and drawings. It was published twice monthly in newspaper format until early 1978 when it changed to a magazine format, with issues averaging 30 pages. The publication ran from 1972 to 1990. Its founding was part of a broader movement at Trenton State College where, following the assassination of Martin Luther King Jr. in April 1968, African American students presented a list of 10 demands to President Robert Heussler, including creation of an Afro-American Studies program, increased Black student enrollment, hiring Black entertainment, and having a dedicated space on campus for Black students. Digitized issues are available through the TCNJ Digital Repository.

publications.name: Bootstrap
publications.historicalNotes: Bootstrap was a Black publication from Newark, NJ, active from approximately 1981 to 1983. No digitized copies or detailed historical records were found online. Newark had a vibrant Black publishing scene during this era; the Newark Public Library's New Jersey Information Center maintains extensive archives of local periodicals from this period, including publications like Grafrica (1981-1982). The Newark Public Library's Charles F. Cummings NJ Information Center would be the most likely repository for physical copies.

publications.name: The Network: The Newsletter of the African-American Institute of Islamic Research
Newark Community Union Project News
publications.historicalNotes: The Newark Community Union Project (NCUP) was established in 1964 as part of the Students for a Democratic Society (SDS) Economic Research and Action Project (ERAP), co-led by Tom Hayden and Carl Wittman. NCUP settled into the Clinton Hill neighborhood in South Newark in the summer of 1964, consisting of about 12-15 organizers (half Black, half white college students and graduates). While a specific newsletter titled 'NCUP News' was not confirmed in online sources, NCUP produced community publications and flyers as part of its organizing work in the predominantly Black Clinton Hill neighborhood. The project focused on housing issues, organizing rent strikes (which were illegal in New Jersey), picketing slumlords' homes, and conducting block meetings to address rats, roaches, unsafe living conditions, and police misconduct. NCUP's work is documented in the 1966 documentary film 'Troublemakers.' By late summer 1965, the project staff had dwindled to about half a dozen organizers, though an estimated 150 local people participated in various programs and meetings. The 1967 Newark Rebellion effectively ended NCUP, as the uprising convinced the remaining white organizers they were unwanted. NCUP's methods -- rent strikes, picketing, block meetings -- had by then spread to other parts of the city. Archival materials may exist at the NYU Tamiment Library, Rutgers University Libraries, or the Library of Congress, which catalogs materials under the subject heading 'Newark Community Union Project (N.J.)'.

publications.name: Fotorama
publications.historicalNotes: Fotorama was a photography magazine with its premiere issue (#1) published in 1993, featuring covergirl Charmaine on the cover. Published out of River Edge, NJ, it was part of the cluster of Black entertainment magazines produced in Bergen County during the early 1990s alongside Word Up!, Hype, and related titles. The magazine appears to have been a celebrity photography publication. Copies of the premiere issue are available through Amazon and vintage magazine dealers, but no digitized archive exists online.

publications.name: The Hiram Star-News
publications.primaryFocus: Community newsletter, King Hiram's Craftsmen Center
publications.historicalNotes: No specific archival or historical records were found for The Hiram Star-News from Vauxhall, NJ in online databases. Vauxhall is an unincorporated community within Union Township, Union County, New Jersey. The 1947 start date places it in the immediate postwar period when African American communities in northern New Jersey were growing due to wartime migration and postwar economic opportunities. The name 'Hiram' may reference a fraternal lodge or community organization, as Hiram lodges were common in African American Freemasonry (Prince Hall Masonry). Physical records may exist at the Union Township Public Library, the Union County Historical Society, or in the Danky & Hady national bibliography.

publications.name: Fire II
publications.publishers: Trenton State College, Fire II Publications
publications.historicalNotes: No digitized archive was found for Fire II from Trenton, NJ (1975). The title is a direct homage to Fire!! A Quarterly Devoted to the Younger Negro Artists, the landmark Harlem Renaissance literary magazine published in 1926 by Wallace Thurman, Zora Neale Hurston, Aaron Douglas, Langston Hughes, Richard Bruce Nugent, Gwendolyn Bennett, and Countee Cullen. The original Fire!! lasted only one issue due to financial problems and a fire that destroyed remaining copies, but it became one of the most significant publications of the Harlem Renaissance for its unflinching treatment of Black life and its challenge to older Black literary conventions. Hughes wrote that the name was intended 'to burn up a lot of the old, dead conventional Negro-white ideas of the past.' Fire II from Trenton (1975) would have emerged during the Black Arts Movement, which explicitly drew inspiration from the Harlem Renaissance. A reprint of the original Fire!! was issued by Negro University Press in Westport, CT (1970) and by FIRE!! Press in Metuchen, NJ (1982), indicating strong New Jersey connections to preserving this legacy. The modern FIYAH Literary Magazine (speculative fiction) also draws on this lineage. Trenton had one of New Jersey's oldest Black communities, with The Sentinel (est. 1880) being among the first African American newspapers in the state.

publications.name: ONI
publications.keyStaff: Editor: Rhashidah Elaine McNeill, Previous editor(s): Elaine McNeill Rhashidali

publications.name: Hype Hair
publications.historicalNotes: Hype Hair was founded in 1992 by editor-in-chief Belinda Trotter, who developed the concept while working as editor-in-chief for the 2 Hype fanzine under the Word Up! publication house in Paramus, NJ. Publisher Scott Figman greenlit the standalone magazine after the hairstyle sections proved enormously popular. Hype Hair became the #1 hair and beauty publication for women of color, published nine times per year featuring hairstyles, beauty products, and celebrity coverage. The magazine was Black women-led since its founding but was only Black-owned from 2013-2017 under UPTOWN Ventures Group. In 2021, Lia Dias (owner of The Girl Cave LA beauty supply stores) purchased the magazine, making it Black-owned again. Dias merged her beauty supply chain with the brand to launch Hype Hair Beauty Supply stores in California and Texas. The magazine is now digital-only, headquartered in Los Angeles.

publications.name: Unity and Struggle
publications.primaryFocus: Socialism, Black Liberation movement, Politics, Education, Employment, Housing, Health
publications.missionStatement: ‘The Struggle Continues”
publications.historicalNotes: Unity and Struggle was the national newspaper of the Congress of Afrikan People (CAP), led by Amiri Baraka. It evolved from earlier Newark Black publications: Black Newark (1968), Black News (1969), and Black New Ark (1972-1973), all published by the Committee for Unified Newark (CFUN). Unity and Struggle was issued by CAP from approximately February/March 1974 through April 1976, then by the Revolutionary Communist League (Marxist-Leninist-Mao Tse Tung Thought) from June 1976 through 1979, reflecting CAP's ideological transition from Black cultural nationalism to Marxism-Leninism. Dr. Komozi Woodard (professor of American history at Sarah Lawrence College and author of 'A Nation Within: Baraka and Black Power Politics') served as editor. The paper covered topics including African liberation, trade unions, factory organizing, and Black political conventions. The August 1974 issue featured coverage of the All-Afrikan Women's Conference held in Newark. The history of CAP was first published in Vol. V, No. 6 (June 1976). Digitized issues are available through the Rutgers Dana Library Newark Black Newspapers Collection (collections.libraries.rutgers.edu/newark-black-newspapers) and individual issues through RiseUp Newark (riseupnewark.com), with credit to the NYU Tamiment Library. Physical copies are held at the Komozi Woodard Amiri Baraka Collection at the Auburn Avenue Research Library, with a distribution list from 1975 preserved in the archive.

publications.name: Black Book Connection, Inc. Newsletter
publications.primaryFocus: Book reviews, Calendar, Books and reading
publications.missionStatement: “Your link to Black authors, Black titles, and Black concerns.”

publications.name: Camp Cooper Chats
publications.keyStaff: Previous editor(s): E. T. Miller, Dec 18 1935-Aug 20 1936; Robert R. Toomer, Oct 20 1936-June 30 1937
publications.historicalNotes: CCC camp newspaper. No CCC camp directly listed for Glen Ridge in the CCC Legacy database; may have been associated with a nearby Essex County camp. CCC camps in New Jersey were segregated by 1935. No digitized copies found online. Further research recommended at the Center for Research Libraries, National Archives Record Group 35, and the book 'The CCC Chronicles: Camp Newspapers of the Civilian Conservation Corps, 1933-1942' by Alfred Emile Cornebise (chapter 8 covers African American experience).

publications.name: Just for Black Men
publications.primaryFocus: Men, Health, Fitness, Art, Entertainment, Lifestyle, Sports

publications.name: Sixty Niner
publications.keyStaff: Previous editor(s): Philip Brown, Oct 1936; Roy Calloway, May 1937; Carl Boyd, Dec 1938; James Roberson, Nov 1940-Feb 1941.

publications.name: The Little Ease Echo
publications.keyStaff: Previous editor(s): Robert Toomer, Dec 1938-June 1939; Joseph Moore, July 1939; Timothy Fenner, Aug-Sept 1939.

publications.name: The Literary Griot
publications.publishers: International Journal of Black Expressive Cultural Studies
publications.primaryFocus: Literature, Short stories, Oral history, Poetry, Art, Film, Theater, Music
publications.missionStatement: “International journal of black oral and literary studies.”

publications.name: Try It Yourself Hair!
publications.keyStaff:
Editor: Adrienne Moore
Previous editor(s): Marcia Cole

publications.name: Dias Creek Echo
publications.publishers: Published by Civilian Conservation Corps, Company 1275-C

publications.name: Right On!
publications.publishers: D.S. Magazines, Inc. (originally Laufer Publishing; founded by Judy Wieder)
publications.missionStatement: Print
publications.historicalNotes: Right On! was the first original fan magazine catering to an African American teen audience, launched in October 1971 by the Laufer Publishing Company. Its first cover stars were The Jackson 5 (Michael, Jermaine, Tito, Jackie, and Marlon Jackson). The magazine was a companion to the white-audience teen magazines Tiger Beat and Bop. Cynthia Horner joined in 1976 as Editorial Director and shaped the magazine's identity for decades, becoming its most notable editor-in-chief. Right On! spawned spinoffs including Word Up! (headquartered in Paramus, NJ, in Bergen County) and Black Beat, all known for centerfold-style pull-out posters. In the 1980s, Right On! became the first publication to cover hip-hop, with stories on The Sugarhill Gang, Grandmaster Flash, and The Furious Five. In the 1990s, the magazine passed through the Sterling/Macfadden publishing conglomerate (formed 1991-1992 when Macfadden's consumer magazines merged with Sterling's Magazines). In 1998, the youth music titles were sold to Primedia; the remaining titles were bought by Dorchester Media in 2004. Right On! ceased regular print publication in 2014. In 2017, Right On! Media Holdings, LLC was formed by Cynthia Horner (CEO), Derrick Horner (Chief Digital Officer), and Kenneth Harris (Chief Marketing Officer) to relaunch as Right On! Digital (rightondigital.com). The Cresskill, NJ listing may reflect a Bergen County office location, as the spinoff Word Up! was based in nearby Paramus, NJ. Some individual issues are available on Internet Archive.

publications.name: Right On! Presents Class
publications.historicalNotes: Right On! Presents Class was a special edition or spin-off publication of Right On! magazine, published in 1983 from Cresskill, NJ. Right On! was first published in 1971 by the Laufer Company as a Black teen entertainment magazine modeled as an African-American counterpart to Tiger Beat. By the early 1980s, under editor-in-chief Cynthia Horner (who took the helm in 1976 at age 21), Right On! was expanding with spin-off titles. 'Class' appears to have been one such spin-off, likely targeting a slightly older or more sophisticated demographic. The Laufer Company and its successors (later Sterling/MacFadden) operated from various NJ locations including Cresskill in Bergen County. No digitized copies were found online.

publications.name: Black Voice/Carta Boricua
publications.primaryFocus: Hispanics, Rutgers University, Colleges and universities — Students
publications.missionStatement: The newspaper is produced by and for Black and Latinx students, with the goal of "Break the Chains of Ignorance" and to develop social, cultural, and political consciousness within the community.

publications.name: Black Caucus of ALA Newsletter
publications.publishers: Black Caucus of the American Library Association (BCALA)
publications.missionStatement: Print

publications.name: Kuumba: The Black Voice Magazine
publications.historicalNotes: No digitized archive was found for Kuumba: The Black Voice Magazine from New Brunswick, NJ (1974-1975). 'Kuumba' is a Swahili word meaning 'creativity,' one of the seven principles of Kwanzaa (Nguzo Saba). The name was widely adopted by Black student organizations and cultural groups during the 1970s Black Arts and Black Power movements. During this period, Rutgers University-New Brunswick had an active Black student community; the Black Voice Carta Latina (BVCL) was a later Black/Hispanic student publication at Rutgers, suggesting a lineage of Black student media on campus. The Scarlet & Black Research Center at Rutgers documents Black voices at the university and may have records. Rutgers University Special Collections and University Archives would be the most likely repository for this student publication. Livingston College, established in 1969 as Rutgers' most diverse residential college, was a hub for Black student activism and publications during this era.

publications.name: Camp Berlin Broadcast
publications.keyStaff:
Previous editor(s): A. W. Reed Jr.,
Nov 24 1934-Feb 14 1935; Ellsworth Miller, Apr 1935.
publications.historicalNotes: CCC camp newspaper. Associated with CCC Camp SP-9 (Company 1275-C), located 1 mile west of Berlin, NJ (Camden County), established October 30, 1933. No digitized copies found online. CCC camps in New Jersey were segregated by 1935 per Director Fechner's order. Further research recommended at the Center for Research Libraries and National Archives Record Group 35.

publications.name: Ujamaa: Journal of the Black Students Union
publications.publishers: William Paterson College, Department of Black Studies
publications.primaryFocus: Colleges and universities — Students, African-American Studies, Poetry, Short stories
publications.keyStaff: Previous editor(s): Lester Forrester, Jan 1974; Eva Byrd, Jan 1974.
publications.historicalNotes: No digitized archive was found for Ujamaa: Journal of the BSU from William Paterson College (now William Paterson University) in Wayne, NJ (1971). 'Ujamaa' is a Swahili word meaning 'cooperative economics' or 'familyhood,' one of the seven principles of Kwanzaa. In 1971, the institution became The William Paterson College of New Jersey, so this publication dates to that transitional year. The name 'Ujamaa' was widely used by Black Student Unions at universities across the country during this era, including Stanford, George Mason, and Evergreen State College. William Paterson's Black Student Union remains active, hosting events such as the annual Black Graduation Ceremony through the Black Cultural Center. The William Paterson University Library Special Collections would be the most likely repository for archival copies of this student journal.

publications.name: Update
publications.primaryFocus: Politics, Race relations, New Jersey Black Issues Convention
publications.missionStatement: “A publication of the New Jersey Black Issues Convention.”

publications.name: Primer
publications.publishers: Published by National Conference of Black and Non-White YMCA Laymen
publications.primaryFocus: National Conference of Black and Non-White YMCA Laymen, Young Men’s Christian Association (YMCA)
publications.historicalNotes: No digitized archive or detailed historical record was found for Primer from East Orange, NJ (1973-1978). The publication does not appear in the Library of Congress newspaper directory, the Wikipedia list of African American newspapers in New Jersey, or the Newark Public Library microfilm inventory. East Orange, in Essex County, had a growing African American population during the 1970s and was served by several Black publications. The Essex Forum (est. 1972) was a biweekly Black newspaper serving Orange, Montclair, and East Orange during the same period. The broader Essex County area was also served by the New Jersey Afro American (Newark, 1941-1991) and the Baraka-era publications (Black NewArk, Unity and Struggle). The East Orange Public Library and the Newark Public Library's New Jersey Information Center (973-733-7775, njreference@npl.org) may hold physical copies. The reference work 'African-American Newspapers and Periodicals: A National Bibliography' (Danky & Hady, Harvard University Press, 1998) may also list this title.

publications.name: NJ-AAHGS Newsletter
publications.publishers: New Jersey Chapter, Afro-American Genealogical Society, Inc.

publications.name: The Black Voice
publications.primaryFocus: Labor, Trade unions, United Black Workers
publications.historicalNotes: The Black Voice was a Newark, NJ publication active from approximately 1972 to 1976, published by the United Black Workers, according to the Newark Public Library's inventory of New Jersey newspapers on microfilm. The publication is held on microfilm at the Newark Public Library's Charles F. Cummings New Jersey Information Center. As a labor-affiliated Black publication, it served a distinct niche from the Baraka-era cultural nationalist newspapers (Black NewArk, Unity and Struggle) that were active in Newark during the same period. The 1970s saw significant Black labor organizing in Newark and New Jersey, with community control of construction projects and War on Poverty programs becoming central to Black economic self-determination. This should not be confused with the Black Voice News of Riverside, California (est. 1972), The Black Voice at Syracuse University (student publication, est. 1969), or the later Rutgers Black Voice Carta Latina (BVCL) student publication. Contact the Newark Public Library's NJ Information Center (973-733-7775, njreference@npl.org) for microfilm access.

publications.name: Educational Perspectives
publications.publishers: Published by National Sorority of PhiDelta Kappa, Inc. Eastern Region
publications.primaryFocus: Phi Delta Kappa Sorority, Education, Fraternities and sororities

publications.name: The Liberator
publications.publishers: Middlesex County College, Central New Jersey Urban Journalism Workshop.
publications.primaryFocus: Journalism, Middlesex County College, Colleges and universities — Students
publications.historicalNotes: No digitized archive was found for The Liberator from Edison, NJ (1970). This should not be confused with the nationally significant Liberator magazine (1961-1971) published in New York City by Daniel H. Watts, which was an influential Black radical publication covering African decolonization, Black Power, and Black nationalism, with contributors including Lorraine Hansberry, James Baldwin, Ossie Davis, Ruby Dee, and Harold Cruse. It is also distinct from William Lloyd Garrison's abolitionist newspaper The Liberator (1831-1865) and Jefferson Lewis Edmonds's Los Angeles-based The Liberator (1900-1914). The Edison, NJ publication does not appear in the Library of Congress directory, the New Jersey State Library's digitized newspaper guides for Middlesex County, or the Wikipedia list of African American newspapers in New Jersey. It may have been a local community newsletter. The Edison Township Public Library and Rutgers University Special Collections may hold records.

publications.name: Captain Africa
publications.historicalNotes: Captain Africa was a Black comic book series created, written, and illustrated by Dwayne J. Ferguson, published by African Prince Productions out of Glen Ridge (and also Somerville), New Jersey. The series debuted with issue #1 in June 1992. The story follows Prince Najee M'Witu, who secretly dons the Falcon Shadow suit of armor (created with his inventor friend Buni Mandella) to protect the high-tech African metropolis of Egyptica from the villain Terror Supreme. Armed with the power of the Black Flame and mastery of the African martial art Kupigani Ngumi, Captain Africa was a pioneering Black superhero of the early 1990s independent comics movement. The series ran three issues (#1 June 1992, #2 October 1993, #3 February 1994) plus an ashcan #0, published through African Prince Productions and Diehard Studios. A graphic novel adaptation, 'Captain Africa: The Battle for Egyptica,' was also published by Africa World Press. Issues are now extremely rare collectors' items. The Internet Archive hosts a borrowable copy of the graphic novel.

publications.name: Wait
publications.keyStaff: Previous editor(s): George S. Adams Jr.

publications.name: Word Up!
publications.historicalNotes: Word Up! debuted in August 1987 as a spin-off of Right On! magazine, headquartered in Paramus, NJ under Enoble Media and publisher John Blassingame. Gerrie Summers served as founding editor-in-chief, shortly after replaced by Kate Ferguson. The magazine was a glossy, visually engaging teen publication featuring hip-hop and R&B artist interviews, pin-ups, fashion tips, a pen pals section called 'Pass the Word,' crossword puzzles, and song lyrics. Principal photographer was Ernie Paniccioli. Word Up! was famously immortalized by The Notorious B.I.G. in 'Juicy' (1994): 'It was all a dream; I used to read Word Up! magazine.' Rap Masters was its sister publication, both produced by Faces Magazines in Paramus. The magazine circulated from 1987-2012, proving indispensable in launching careers of countless hip-hop and R&B legends. In the 2020s, Cynthia Horner (former Right On! editor-in-chief) purchased both titles, forming Right On! Media Holdings, LLC. In 2023, the Notorious B.I.G. Estate partnered with Budweiser to release limited-edition tribute issues (5,000 copies each) during Hip-Hop 50 celebrations.

publications.name: Monthly Black Periodicals Selection Review
publications.historicalNotes: No digitized archive or detailed record was found for the Monthly Black Periodicals Selection Review from Newark, NJ (1973). The title suggests this was a library or bibliographic review publication that surveyed and recommended Black periodicals for library acquisition, rather than a community newspaper. Newark was home to several major library and information science institutions during this period. The Newark Public Library's Charles F. Cummings New Jersey Information Center maintains extensive archives and may have been connected to this publication. The 1970s saw a significant expansion of Black studies programs and library collections focused on African American materials, which would have created demand for a periodicals selection guide. This publication may be cataloged in library science databases or held in special collections at library schools.
