publications.publishers: Afro-American Historical and Genealogical Society, Inc., New Jersey Chapter.
publications.missionStatement: “A celebration of African American history & genealogy.”

publications.name: Inner City Products
publications.missionStatement: Near-future corporate super-villains (Inner-city Products) attempt to undo African American social progress by time-traveling to the late 20th century to thwart hip-hop culture.

publications.name: Gospel Today Magazine
publications.publishers: Dr. Teresa Hairston, Founder & Publisher Emeritus
publications.primaryFocus: Gospel music, Music, Religion, Book reviews, Video reviews
publications.keyStaff: Dr. Teresa Hairston (Founder); Roland T. Hairston II (Co-publisher 2011-2012)
publications.historicalNotes: Gospel Today was founded in 1989 by Dr. Teresa Hairston as a four-page newsletter, launched with just $300 while she was a divorced mother of three working two jobs. The newsletter grew into the longest-running and most widely distributed Urban Christian Lifestyle magazine in history. In 1992, Hairston launched companion publication SCOREBOARD (a gospel music industry trade journal), which later became Gospel Industry Today. Content expanded from gospel music coverage to all aspects of Christian lifestyle, featuring interviews with Denzel Washington, Whitney Houston, Evander Holyfield, Jesse Jackson, and others. At its peak, Gospel Today had a circulation of 240,000. In 2008, Lifeway Christian Bookstores pulled the magazine from shelves after it featured women pastors on its cover, conflicting with Southern Baptist beliefs. The magazine never fully recovered. Hairston stepped down in 2011, passing leadership to her son Roland T. Hairston II. The magazine transitioned to digital-only before ceasing operations circa 2013. Hairston also created the Gospel Today TV show (Word TV network) and founded the Gospel Heritage Foundation (1994). Her archival collection, including magazines, audio interviews, 5,000+ sound recordings, and promotional materials, was donated to Indiana University's Archives of African American Music and Culture (AAAMC) in 2016. Hairston published her memoir 'Unstoppable' in 2021.

publications.name: Black Atlantic City Magazine
publications.primaryFocus: General interest, Entertainment, Atlantic City, NJ

publications.name: Write On Newsletter

publications.name: Testimony: A Journal of African-American Poetry
publications.historicalNotes: Testimony: A Journal of African-American Poetry was a quarterly poetry journal published out of Montclair, NJ, edited by Sandra West. Two issues were published in 1987: Vol. 1, Issue One (Winter 1987) and Vol. 1, Issue Two (Spring 1987). Each issue was in 8.5x11 inch stapled wraps, running 30-34 pages. Issue One contained poetry on Black life, Black uplift, and Black alienation. Issue Two explored the political landscape with a pan-African scope, featuring poems including 'Apartheid,' 'Why Malcolm Had to Leave,' 'Frustrations of a NeoRevolutionary,' and 'Political FatCats.' Notable contributor Sonia Sanchez contributed 'MIA's (Missing in action and other atlantas).' The journal is extremely rare: only four institutional holdings are recorded in OCLC (Rutgers University, New York Public Library, Williams College, and Newark Public Library). No copies are known to be in commerce. The journal represents Montclair's role as a center of Black literary activity in northern New Jersey during the 1980s.

publications.name: The Hart Fund

publications.name: The Best of Rap & R&B
publications.primaryFocus: Music, Hip hop culture, Rap music, Rhythm and Blues
publications.historicalNotes: The Best of Rap & R&B was a music publication from Paramus, NJ, published in 1988. It was likely produced by one of the teen entertainment publishing companies based in the Paramus area (Sterling's Magazines or MacFadden, which formally merged in 1991-1992). These companies published multiple fan and music magazines including Right On!, Teen Beat, 16 Magazine, Tiger Beat, and Metal Edge. The Best of Rap & R&B appears to have been a special edition or compilation publication capitalizing on the late-1980s explosion of hip-hop and R&B. No digitized copies or detailed publication records were found online.

publications.name: Black Women’s United Front Newsletter

publications.missionStatement: “Abolition of every possibility of oppression and exploitation that’s our slogan!”

publications.name: Newark Black Newspapers Collection | Digital Collections
publications.historicalNotes: This is NOT a newspaper. It is a digital library collection hosted by Rutgers University Libraries at collections.libraries.rutgers.edu/newark-black-newspapers. The collection contains four newspapers published under the leadership of Amiri Baraka (Leroi Jones) between 1968 and 1979 during Newark's post-rebellion period: (1) Black Newark, Vol. 1 No. 1-3, April-November 1968; (2) Black News, published by Black People of Newark, Vol. 1 No. 4, 1969; (3) Black New Ark, published by Committee for Unified Newark, Vol. 1 No. 5 (April 1972) - Vol. 2 No. 14 (Dec. 1973), incomplete; (4) Unity and Struggle, published by Committee for Unified Newark, Vol. 3 No. 1 (Jan/Feb 1974) - Vol. 8 No. 1/2 (Feb. 1979), incomplete. The collection is digitized from holdings at the Rutgers Dana Library and is fully searchable. These newspapers served as tools for activism, organizing, and advocating for Black liberation and political and economic agency. This entry should be reclassified as a 'collection' rather than a standalone newspaper.

publications.name: Club World: Newsmagazine

publications.name: Communique: Quarterly Newsletter of the New Jersey Coalition of 100 Black Women
publications.publishers: Published by New Jersey Coalition of 100 Black Women
publications.historicalNotes: Communique was a newsletter published by the New Jersey chapter of the National Coalition of 100 Black Women, based in East Orange, NJ, circa 1983. The National Coalition of 100 Black Women, Inc. was founded in 1981 to advocate on behalf of Black women and girls, promoting leadership development and gender equity in health, education, and economic empowerment. Multiple NJ chapters exist today, including Bergen/Passaic (founded 1986) and Southern NJ chapters. The East Orange chapter's newsletter would have documented early organizing activities of this nationally significant organization. No digitized copies were found; the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture or local East Orange archives may hold physical copies.
